text:
GREEN BAY (WLUK) -- As the United States prepares to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement, utilities in Wisconsin are ramping up their clean energy initiatives.

The Environmental Protection Agency reports that the electric power sector contributes about 25% of all U.S. greenhouse gas emissions.

Wisconsin Public Service is actively working to reduce this impact by expanding its renewable energy facilities, including solar, hydroelectric and wind energy.

"We provide reliable clean energy to our customers every day using our renewable energy facilities," WPS spokesperson Matt Cullen said.

WPS recently launched Wisconsin's first large-scale battery storage facility, which stores energy for later use when demand is high. Additionally, WPS offers programs like NatureWise and the renewable pathway program, allowing customers and businesses to choose how their electricity is generated.

Despite the end of federal tax credits for solar panel installations, WPS customers can still benefit from clean energy projects, which have provided tens of millions of dollars in savings. WPS aims to be net carbon neutral by 2050 and has already reduced emissions by 56% since 2005.

title: Trump administration officials tout auto changes at Detroit Auto Show - USA Today
description:
High-level federal officials visited the first public day of the 2026 Detroit Auto Show to tour cars and talk about how the auto industry has changed in the first year of President Donald Trump's second term.
The average age of a vehicle on American roads is 13, which is "way too old," Secretary of Transportation Sean Duffy said.
Before heading to Detroit, the officials made stops at manufacturing plants in Ohio and appeared at the Toledo Auto Show this week.
Ford CEO Jim Farley also made an appearance at the Detroit Auto Show on Saturday and chatted with the federal officials.
The 2026 Detroit Auto Show is open to the public through Jan. 25.
text:
High-level federal officials visited the first public day of the 2026 Detroit Auto Show to tour cars and talk about how the auto industry has changed in the first year of President Donald Trump's second term.

U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer said there have been "huge strides toward affordability" through regulation cuts and an increased focus on producing cars in America.

The average age of a vehicle on American roads is 13, which is "way too old," Secretary of Transportation Sean Duffy said.

"If we have more affordable cars and more people can put a new car in their driveway, those are safer cars," Duffy said. "That's what we want for American families and that's why this affordable push is so critical."

Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Lee Zeldin blamed the high cost of new cars on car companies feeling like they had to focus on EVs. The officials said Trump ending what they called the "EV mandate" — referring to Biden-era government incentives for companies to create more EVs in order to avoid greenhouse gas emissions — was one of the administration's biggest moves to help the auto industry.

"When government policy is dictating to the manufacturer what kind of a vehicle they have to create, even though Americans don't want it, that comes with a cost," Zeldin said. "When you have to be hiring workers, and you have plants built, and you're spending all that time, energy and money, and you're doing the research, and the development, to come up with a vehicle that Americans do not want to buy, that causes prices to go up."

Advocates for government incentives to increase EV production say it's an important step in reducing greenhouse gas emissions that enact climate change.

In December, Trump announced he was rolling back the Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) standards for cars and trucks set by the Biden administration, which required automakers to increase the miles per gallon for new cars and encouraged electric vehicle production, USA TODAY reported.

"Their decision on CAFE standards, the significance of it to benefit the U.S. market and American consumer to make it realistic and practical to apply common sense," Zeldin said.

Earlier in 2025, Trump signed legislation that ended fuel economy penalties for automakers.

Zeldin also cited the EPA push to eliminate the credit automakers received for implementing start-stop, the feature that automatically turns the engine off when a car is idling, as a push for affordability.

Before heading to Detroit, the officials made stops at manufacturing plants in Ohio and appeared at the Toledo Auto Show this week.

Ford CEO Jim Farley also made an appearance at the Detroit Auto Show on Saturday and chatted with the federal officials.

The officials toured cars behind display cases and walked around the show as thousands of people checked out hundreds of cars and mingled on the show floor.

The 2026 Detroit Auto Show is open to the public through Jan. 25. Information about how to buy tickets can be found at detroitautoshow.com.

name: Clean Energy
title: Court deems US administration illegally canceled nearly $8B in crucial projects - Yahoo
description:
One federal judge isn't buying what the Trump administration is selling on nearly $8 billion worth of canceled energy projects in blue states.
The $7.6 billion of energy projects included support for hydrogen initiatives, carbon capture, battery plants, and electric grid updates.
But the clean energy sector can boost jobs, reduce dependence on dirty fuels like oil and gas, and cut down on pollution.
What's being done about clean energy projects in America?
States, clean energy advocates, and municipalities are continuing to challenge the Trump administration's dubious moves.
text:
One federal judge isn't buying what the Trump administration is selling on nearly $8 billion worth of canceled energy projects in blue states.

What's happening?

U.S. district judge Amit Mehta determined that the Trump administration acted unlawfully when it singled out states that voted for Kamala Harris in the 2024 election, as the AP reported.

The $7.6 billion of energy projects included support for hydrogen initiatives, carbon capture, battery plants, and electric grid updates. They were set to take place in 16 states, including California, Massachusetts, and Washington.

"Defendants freely admit that they made grant-termination decisions primarily — if not exclusively — based on whether the awardee resided in a state whose citizens voted for President Trump in 2024," Mehta wrote.

Clean energy advocates supported that claim by noting that similar projects in Texas, among other red states, were left alone.

The Trump administration pushed back on the ruling. Energy Department spokesman Ben Dietderich insisted that officials "evaluated these awards individually and determined they did not meet the standards necessary to justify the continued spending of taxpayer dollars."

The Environmental Defense Fund was one of the groups that filed the suit, and its general counsel, Vickie Patton, was having none of that explanation.

Patton argued the Department of Energy "vindictively canceled projects for clean affordable energy that just happened to be in states disfavored by the Trump administration," per the AP.

Why is the Trump administration's hostility to many types of clean energy important?

While this ruling serves as another loss to the Trump administration, it's becoming clearer that it will continue to obstruct many types of clean energy projects (it has shown support for select low-carbon endeavors, such as nuclear). But the clean energy sector can boost jobs, reduce dependence on dirty fuels like oil and gas, and cut down on pollution.

As energy bills are on the rise due to AI and data centers, expanding the energy mix will be critical to keeping up with demand. There's also the issue of fairness and political targeting.

Many of these projects are supported by the local community and provide employment opportunities and long-term benefits. As Patton argued, stripping them as retaliation for votes in an election is a petty move that flies in the face of the Constitution.

What's being done about clean energy projects in America?

States, clean energy advocates, and municipalities are continuing to challenge the Trump administration's dubious moves. On Monday, a judge allowed a long-awaited offshore wind project in Rhode Island and Connecticut to go forward despite a similar cancellation bid, per the AP.

Judicial decisions will continue to play a crucial role in maintaining momentum in the nation's clean energy efforts and ensuring that political biases do not stall progress beneficial to communities.

title: Syrah Tesla Graphite Deal: Battery Supply Chain Update - Discovery Alert
description:
The Syrah Resources Tesla graphite supply deal illustrates these broader systemic challenges, as Tesla's pursuit of non-Chinese graphite processing capabilities has encountered repeated technical delays.
Chinese companies control an estimated 65-70% of global natural graphite production and approximately 90-95% of spherical graphite manufacturing capacity worldwide.
Alternative Supply Chain Scenarios and Market Implications The outcome of the Syrah Resources Tesla graphite supply deal will influence broader industry approaches to battery supply chain diversification.
Strategic partnerships see more automotive companies exploring long-term supply agreements, while geopolitical considerations drive government support for supply chain diversification initiatives.
However, effectiveness depends on successful private sector execution, as demonstrated by the ongoing Syrah Resources Tesla graphite supply deal technical challenges.
text:
Battery Supply Chain Vulnerabilities in the Global Energy Transition

The shift towards electrified transportation has exposed critical vulnerabilities in how advanced economies secure essential battery materials. Modern electric vehicle manufacturing faces unprecedented challenges as automakers navigate increasingly complex supply chains for critical battery materials. The Syrah Resources Tesla graphite supply deal illustrates these broader systemic challenges, as Tesla's pursuit of non-Chinese graphite processing capabilities has encountered repeated technical delays.

Furthermore, this transition from fossil fuel dependence to electrified transportation has highlighted fundamental weaknesses in sourcing, processing, and securing access to essential minerals. Among these materials, graphite represents a particularly acute bottleneck, with processing capabilities concentrated in regions that may not align with strategic interests of major automotive markets. This case study reveals critical insights about supply chain diversification, technical specification challenges, and the intersection of industrial policy with private sector risk management.

Understanding Graphite's Critical Role in Battery Manufacturing

Natural graphite serves as the foundation for lithium-ion battery anode production, comprising approximately 90-95% of anode material by weight in most commercial battery designs. This proportion makes graphite the largest single component in battery cells, yet it receives significantly less attention than lithium, cobalt, or nickel in public discussions about critical minerals energy transition strategies.

The transformation from raw graphite flakes to battery-ready active anode material (AAM) requires sophisticated processing capabilities that few facilities outside China currently possess. Consequently, the conversion process involves several critical steps that demonstrate the complexity of establishing alternative supply chains.

The conversion process involves:

Spherical shaping: Raw graphite flakes must be mechanically processed into spherical particles

Purification: Achieving battery-grade purity levels above 99.95% carbon content

Coating application: Surface treatments to improve electrochemical performance

Size classification: Precise particle size distribution control for optimal battery performance

Battery-grade graphite specifications differ substantially from industrial applications. Automotive battery cells require consistent particle sizes typically ranging from 10-25 micrometers, with strict controls on impurity levels, surface area characteristics, and electrochemical properties. The Tesla 4680 battery cells demand particularly stringent specifications due to their larger format and higher energy density requirements.

However, processing yields from raw graphite to finished AAM typically range from 75-85%, meaning substantial material losses occur during qualification. These technical requirements explain why establishing new AAM production capabilities outside established supply chains presents such formidable challenges.

Chinese Market Concentration and Strategic Implications

China's dominance in graphite processing stems from decades of industrial development combined with access to both domestic and imported raw materials. Chinese companies control an estimated 65-70% of global natural graphite production and approximately 90-95% of spherical graphite manufacturing capacity worldwide.

In addition, this concentration creates multiple vulnerability points for Western automotive manufacturers. Supply security risks include trade policy disruptions affecting graphite exports, quality control challenges with distant suppliers, currency fluctuations impacting long-term pricing, and potential export restrictions on strategic materials.

Technical Integration Challenges

Limited visibility into Chinese processing methods

Difficulty customising specifications for specific battery chemistries

Intellectual property concerns around advanced coating technologies

Quality consistency variations between different Chinese suppliers

The Syrah Resources Tesla graphite supply deal represents one of the most significant attempts to establish large-scale AAM production outside Chinese control. Syrah's Vidalia facility integrates raw material from the company's Mozambique mining operations with processing capabilities designed to serve North American automotive markets.

However, the repeated deadline extensions in this partnership illustrate the technical complexity of replicating established Chinese processing capabilities. Tesla issued its first default notice in July 2025, citing failures to deliver conforming AAM samples. Subsequent deadline extensions to November 2025, January 2026, and now March 2026 demonstrate the challenges involved in achieving automotive-grade specifications.

Technical Specification Challenges and Quality Control

The ongoing difficulties between Tesla and Syrah Resources highlight fundamental challenges in AAM production that extend beyond simple manufacturing scale-up. Automotive battery specifications require precise control over multiple technical parameters that affect both performance and safety.

What Are the Key Electrochemical Performance Standards?

Battery-grade graphite must demonstrate consistent performance across multiple test protocols. Furthermore, these standards represent critical benchmarks that distinguish automotive-grade materials from consumer electronics applications.

Coulombic efficiency: First-cycle efficiency typically above 92%

Cycling stability: Capacity retention over 1,000+ charge cycles

Rate capability: Performance at various charging speeds

Thermal stability: Safe operation across temperature ranges

SEI formation: Predictable solid electrolyte interface development

Particle Engineering Requirements

The conversion to spherical graphite requires precise control over multiple technical parameters. For instance, size distribution must maintain narrow particle size ranges for consistent packing, while surface morphology requires smooth surfaces for optimal electrolyte contact.

Tap density: Achieving target volumetric energy density

BET surface area: Controlling reactive surface area for safety

Syrah's challenges in meeting Tesla's specifications likely relate to one or more of these technical parameters. The company does not accept it is in default under the offtake agreement, suggesting disagreement about whether specification failures represent fundamental process deficiencies or addressable quality control issues.

The collaborative approach described in recent statements indicates both parties view the technical challenges as solvable rather than representing fundamental incompatibility. Tesla retains termination rights through February 9, 2026, providing additional pressure for resolution while maintaining the partnership framework.

Financial Structure and Risk Allocation in Battery Supply Agreements

The Tesla-Syrah agreement structure reflects broader trends in how automotive companies approach critical material sourcing. The four-year commitment for 8,000 tonnes annually provides Syrah with demand certainty while giving Tesla access to non-Chinese AAM production capacity.

Offtake Agreement Mechanics

Component Details Risk Allocation Volume Commitment 8,000 tonnes/year (32,000 total) Tesla demand risk Duration Four years from first delivery Long-term price stability Quality Standards Automotive-grade AAM specifications Syrah technical risk Termination Rights Performance-based with cure periods Shared resolution incentive

This structure differs from traditional commodity purchasing through spot markets or short-term contracts. The long-term commitment provides capital investment justification for Syrah while ensuring Tesla access to strategic materials outside Chinese supply chains.

Pricing mechanisms in such agreements typically include escalation clauses tied to inflation, energy costs, or raw material input prices. The specific pricing structure between Tesla and Syrah remains undisclosed, but likely includes provisions for cost adjustments given the volatile nature of battery metals investment markets.

Performance-Based Risk Management

The multiple deadline extensions reveal sophisticated risk management approaches in battery supply agreements. Rather than immediate termination upon specification failures, the partnership structure includes several collaborative elements.

Cure periods: Opportunities to address technical deficiencies

Collaborative resolution: Joint problem-solving rather than adversarial enforcement

Regulatory coordination: DOE approval requirements for modifications

Termination triggers: Clear performance deadlines with exit options

Government Support and Industrial Policy Integration

The Syrah Vidalia project benefits from substantial federal support designed to establish domestic battery material supply chains. The U.S. Department of Energy has provided comprehensive financial backing including loans, grants, and tax credits totalling approximately $487 million across the project lifecycle.

Federal Funding Structure

DOE Loan Program: $102 million in debt financing

Grant Funding: $220 million for facility construction

Tax Credits: $165 million through various federal programmes

This level of government support reflects recognition that battery recycling breakthrough developments and supply chain establishment require coordination between public and private sector investments. The Inflation Reduction Act provides additional policy framework supporting domestic battery manufacturing through production tax credits and supply chain requirements.

Strategic Mineral Classification

Graphite's designation as a critical mineral under various federal frameworks enables this level of support. The classification recognises that supply chain concentration creates national security vulnerabilities, private sector investment alone may be insufficient to establish alternative suppliers, and coordination with allied nations requires compatible supply chain infrastructure.

The DOE involvement in contract modifications between Tesla and Syrah demonstrates how government support creates additional stakeholders in private commercial relationships. Approval requirements for deadline extensions reflect federal interest in ensuring taxpayer-supported projects achieve intended strategic objectives.

Production Scaling and Industrial Benchmarking

Syrah's operational timeline illustrates the complexity of establishing new AAM production capabilities from greenfield development through commercial qualification. However, establishing Australia's strategic minerals reserve requires similar coordination between private sector capabilities and government strategic objectives.

Development Milestones

Phase Timeline Achievement Next Steps Construction 2022-2023 Facility completion Equipment commissioning Initial Production Q4 2023 Unpurified spherical graphite Process optimisation AAM Production Q1 2024 Active anode material output Quality qualification Commercial Validation 2024-2025 Customer specification trials Volume scaling

The facility's current capacity of 11,250 tonnes annually positions it as a significant supplier in North American markets. Furthermore, expansion potential to 45,000 tonnes represents meaningful competition to Chinese imports.

Industry Benchmarking

Established AAM producers typically require 18-24 months for customer qualification cycles, making Syrah's extended timeline, while challenging, not unprecedented in the industry. Processing efficiency targets of 85-90% represent standard expectations for mature operations.

Automotive specifications generally require higher consistency than consumer electronics applications, explaining the extended validation periods compared to other battery market segments. The distinction between automotive and consumer-grade materials creates different market segments with varying price premiums and specification requirements.

Alternative Supply Chain Scenarios and Market Implications

The outcome of the Syrah Resources Tesla graphite supply deal will influence broader industry approaches to battery supply chain diversification. Several scenarios could reshape market dynamics depending on technical resolution success or partnership dissolution.

Success Scenario: Technical Validation Achievement

If Syrah meets Tesla's specifications by the March 2026 deadline, several market impacts become likely. Proof of concept demonstration that non-Chinese AAM production can achieve automotive specifications would provide volume scaling pathways to full 8,000 tonne annual production capacity.

Additional partnerships with other automotive manufacturers may pursue similar agreements, while investment replication could encourage similar projects from competitors. These developments would occur alongside broader US‑China trade impacts on global supply chain strategies.

Risk Scenario: Partnership Dissolution

Partnership termination would create different market dynamics. Tesla would need to accelerate relationships with other graphite suppliers, while Syrah would focus on consumer electronics and energy storage markets.

Consequently, the investment community would reassess non-Chinese supply chain development risks, potentially leading to revision of federal support strategies. These outcomes would influence policy implications for future critical mineral development initiatives.

Competitive Landscape Evolution

Regardless of immediate outcomes, the partnership has already influenced industry development. Other graphite projects have attracted increased investor interest in North American graphite development, while technology advancement continues improving yields and reducing costs.

Strategic partnerships see more automotive companies exploring long-term supply agreements, while geopolitical considerations drive government support for supply chain diversification initiatives.

Investment Framework for Critical Mineral Supply Chains

The Syrah-Tesla partnership provides insights for investors evaluating critical mineral supply chain opportunities across multiple commodities and processing stages. In addition, successful investment requires comprehensive evaluation across multiple technical and market dimensions.

Due Diligence Considerations

Successful investment in battery material supply chains requires evaluation across multiple dimensions. Technical capabilities include processing expertise and yield optimisation potential, quality control systems for automotive specifications, scalability of production processes, and intellectual property considerations.

Market Positioning

Customer validation and automotive qualifications

Geographic diversification benefits

Cost competitiveness versus established suppliers

Long-term contract security and pricing mechanisms

Policy Alignment

Government support availability and sustainability

Regulatory compliance and environmental standards

National security considerations and strategic mineral classification

International cooperation frameworks and trade policy consistency

Financial Structure Analysis

Investment evaluation must consider the extended development timelines characteristic of battery material projects. Capital intensity involves high upfront investments with extended payback periods, while cash flow timing depends on customer qualification completion.

Government support serves as risk mitigation versus market price subsidies, however, exit strategies remain limited during development phases. These factors require careful consideration when evaluating investment opportunities in the sector.

Regulatory Framework Evolution and Market Development

Federal policy development continues shaping market conditions for domestic battery material production through multiple regulatory channels. Recent policy developments create institutional support for supply chain diversification across various frameworks.

Critical Minerals Security Frameworks

Recent policy developments create institutional support for supply chain diversification. The Defense Production Act offers potential applications to graphite processing capacity, while trade policy coordination affects tariff structures on Chinese graphite imports.

Environmental regulations may favour domestic production, while technology transfer enables international cooperation agreements with allied nations. These frameworks indicate sustained government commitment to reducing import dependence for critical battery materials.

Investment Incentive Structures

The Inflation Reduction Act and related legislation create financial incentives for domestic battery supply chain development. Production tax credits provide incentives based on qualifying material output, while investment tax credits support capital expenditure for facility development.

Grant programmes offer direct federal funding for strategic projects, while loan guarantees provide risk sharing for large-scale industrial investments. However, effectiveness depends on successful private sector execution, as demonstrated by the ongoing Syrah Resources Tesla graphite supply deal technical challenges.

Strategic Implications for Industry Evolution

The Syrah Resources Tesla graphite supply deal represents more than a bilateral commercial relationship; it serves as a critical test case for broader supply chain transformation strategies across the battery materials sector.

The extended timeline for technical qualification demonstrates that establishing alternative supply chains requires sustained commitment from both commercial partners and supporting government institutions. Success or failure will influence industry confidence in pursuing similar diversification strategies across other critical materials including lithium hydroxide, battery-grade nickel sulfate, and high-purity cobalt compounds.

Market development beyond Chinese supply chains ultimately depends on achieving cost competitiveness while maintaining quality standards. The Syrah project's outcomes will provide crucial data on whether non-Chinese production can achieve these dual objectives at commercial scale.

Furthermore, the partnership's resolution will establish precedents for similar agreements across the battery materials sector. Successful technical validation would encourage broader industry investment in alternative supply chains, while partnership dissolution might prompt reassessment of diversification strategies and government support mechanisms.

Investment Disclaimer: This analysis contains forward-looking statements and speculative assessments about market developments, technical capabilities, and commercial outcomes. Battery material supply chain investments involve significant risks including technical failure, regulatory changes, and market volatility. Past performance of similar projects does not guarantee future results. Investors should conduct independent due diligence and consider consulting qualified financial advisors before making investment decisions.

text:
British motorists are facing a significant barrier to switching to electric vehicles, according to The Times.

What's happening?

A recent survey by Autotrader showed that the U.K.'s move to charge EV drivers a per-mile tax has had a cooling effect on adoption.

Nearly half of respondents said they were less likely to make their next car an EV due to the new fee, which comes into effect in April 2028. It would add roughly an additional $325 to owners' expenses each year.

The move runs counter to the British government's stated goal of accelerating EV adoption, leading Autotrader CEO Nathan Coe to call the new tax "incoherent and inconsistent," per The Times.

Part of the issue is that the U.K.'s EV transition has been so successful. Government revenue from taxes on gas sales has dropped; this EV levy could make up 25% of the shortfall.

"All cars contribute to the wear and tear on our roads," Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves said during the 2025 budget announcement. "I will ensure that drivers are taxed according to how much they drive and not just by the type of car they own by introducing the EV Excise Duty on electric cars."

Why is EV adoption important?

Electric vehicles are cheaper to run than gas cars, making the switch a major cost-of-living improvement.

On top of that, they release no tailpipe pollution. That means better local air quality and less pollution going into the atmosphere to exacerbate destructive weather patterns.

What's being done about EV adoption in the U.K.?

"We need more carrot and less stick if we're serious about the electric transition," said Ian Plummer, Autotrader's Chief Customer Officer. "The Chancellor clearly needs to raise revenue, but if she wants to encourage EV adoption, she should think extremely carefully before introducing pay-per-mile charging for EVs.

"Drivers respond to incentives, and anything that puts up running costs for electric vehicles will slow that momentum. We've already seen changes to Vehicle Excise Duty this year, making the cost of driving new EVs more expensive."

Luckily, public consultations on the fees remain open until March.

title: Changan ramps up battery EV production in Thailand - Bangkok Post
description:
Chinese electric vehicle maker Changan Automobile is gearing up to launch the second phase of its battery electric vehicle (BEV) production in Thailand in the first quarter of 2026, reinforcing its ambitions in one of Southeast Asia's fastest‑growing EV markets.
"Both phases will level up our total capacity to 200,000 units a year," Mr Atthawit said.
Until then, the company will continue to import batteries from Time Changan, a joint venture between Changan Automobile and CATL in China.
Changan reported sales of around 12,000 units between January and November 2025, up from 7,000 in the same period of 2024.
He said Changan is preparing to adjust its production plans once the government's EV3.0 and EV3.5 subsidies expire.
text:
Chinese electric vehicle maker Changan Automobile is gearing up to launch the second phase of its battery electric vehicle (BEV) production in Thailand in the first quarter of 2026, reinforcing its ambitions in one of Southeast Asia's fastest‑growing EV markets.

"We will start selling BEVs in April," said Atthawit Techawiboonwong, general manager for government affairs at Changan International Corporation.

The company set an annual production capacity for the second phase of 100,000 units, matching the output target of the first phase, which ran through 2025.

"Both phases will level up our total capacity to 200,000 units a year," Mr Atthawit said.

Construction of Changan's battery manufacturing plant is nearing completion and is expected to begin supplying packs to the company's Rayong assembly facility next year. Until then, the company will continue to import batteries from Time Changan, a joint venture between Changan Automobile and CATL in China.

Changan's long‑term strategy positions Thailand as its regional BEV hub, serving both domestic and global markets.

The automaker plans to export Thai‑built EVs to Australia, New Zealand, Indonesia, Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore and Europe.

Over time, exports are expected to account for 55% of output, with the remaining 45% sold locally.

Between 2026 and 2028, Changan intends to roll out seven new models as it pushes to become one of Thailand's top three BEV brands by 2030.

"Changan already produces the Deepal 05, a compact electric SUV in the B‑SUV segment, while the Deepal S07 SUV is expected to enter production in the first quarter of next year," Mr Atthawit said.

The company also aims to deepen its local supply chain, targeting 70% locally sourced components worth more than 3 billion baht by 2027, rising to 80% or 6 billion baht by 2030, up from about 50% today.

Changan reported sales of around 12,000 units between January and November 2025, up from 7,000 in the same period of 2024. The company set a full‑year target of 15,000 units.

He said Changan is preparing to adjust its production plans once the government's EV3.0 and EV3.5 subsidies expire.

Meanwhile, the company's parent firm in China is undergoing restructuring after the Chinese government acquired shares in Changan as part of efforts to stabilise an EV sector facing intense competition and financial strain.

name: EPA
title: EPA Rule Clarification Hits a Significant Source of Grok's Electricity - Gizmodo
authors: Mike Pearl, Ellyn Lapointe, AJ Dellinger, Matt Novak, Bruce Gil
description:
That temporary status, it was apparently hoped, would have made them exempt from air quality requirements.
The newly updated EPA rules clarify that using such turbines, even temporarily, does not confer any such exemption from clean air rules.
The Guardian’s reporting also notes that xAI now has locally permitted generators at the sites, but that the new EPA rules say the federal government is now in charge of such permitting, not the local authorities.
Gizmodo also asked xAI if the Colossus data centers are operating at reduced capacity while the permitting issues are being resolved.
We will update if we receive a useful response.
text:
This past summer, activists at the Southern Environmental Law Center (SELC) announced they were going after Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, for what it claimed were “unpermitted gas turbines that threaten to make air pollution problems even worse,” in the Memphis area, where the xAI “Colossus” data centers are located. It appears the SELC has now prevailed, because the language of a general ruling from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regarding that type of turbine essentially confirms the activists’ assertion, undermining the Grok parent company’s legal rubric for using the equipment.

In order to serve the computational needs of products like the Grok AI chatbot, Grokipedia, and the Grok image generator, xAI was generating off-grid power for its data center with gas-powered turbines and classifying them as “non-road engines”—temporary generators, ostensibly used for more transitory purposes. That temporary status, it was apparently hoped, would have made them exempt from air quality requirements. The newly updated EPA rules clarify that using such turbines, even temporarily, does not confer any such exemption from clean air rules.

According to the Guardian, the placement of the initial “Colossus 1” turbines—which eventually came to number 35—benefited from a local loophole in environmental laws that says generators don’t require permits as long as they’re in place for 364 days or less. The Guardian’s reporting also notes that xAI now has locally permitted generators at the sites, but that the new EPA rules say the federal government is now in charge of such permitting, not the local authorities.

In a statement published by the NAACP, SELC senior attorney Amanda Garcia said this decision “makes it clear that companies are not—and have never been—allowed to build and operate methane gas turbines without a permit and that there is no loophole that would allow corporations to set up unpermitted power plants,” adding that her organization expects “local health leaders to take swift action to ensure they are following federal law and to better protect neighbors from harmful air pollution.”

This feels like a lifetime ago, but just under a year ago, during Elon Musk’s tenure at DOGE, Musk sought to slash EPA contracts with the stated aim of reducing government waste. The EPA’s administrator, Lee Zeldin, said at the time, “DOGE is making us better,” adding, “They come up with great recommendations, and we can make a decision to act on it.”

xAI’s media contact email address sends a three-word auto-reply in response to all inquiries, including one from Gizmodo about what the turbine situation currently is for the relevant facilities in Tennessee. Gizmodo also asked xAI if the Colossus data centers are operating at reduced capacity while the permitting issues are being resolved. We will update if we receive a useful response.

name: Clean Energy
title: Bottleneck in hydrogen distribution jeopardises billions in clean energy - EurekAlert!
description:
A recent study from Edinburgh Business School at Heriot-Watt University found that while hydrogen production, storage and fuel cell technologies are advancing rapidly, the hydrogen distribution infrastructure is developing at half the speed, creating a critical bottleneck that could put billions in clean energy at risk.
Dr David Dekker, a research fellow at Edinburgh Business School, Heriot-Watt University and the paper’s lead author, said: "Distribution will become the dominant cost in any hydrogen system.

text:
A recent study from Edinburgh Business School at Heriot-Watt University found that while hydrogen production, storage and fuel cell technologies are advancing rapidly, the hydrogen distribution infrastructure is developing at half the speed, creating a critical bottleneck that could put billions in clean energy at risk.

The findings, published in the journal Sustainable Futures, are an important milestone in recognising that, while other hydrogen technologies improve and costs fall, distribution expenses could take up a large share of hydrogen system budgets, significantly limiting overall efficiency and growth of the hydrogen sector.

The research team analysed 777,000 patents and 1.3 million citations spanning 182 years of hydrogen technology development, revealing clear differences in progress across the system.

Dr David Dekker, a research fellow at Edinburgh Business School, Heriot-Watt University and the paper’s lead author, said: "Distribution will become the dominant cost in any hydrogen system. Even as we get better at producing and using hydrogen, getting it where it's needed stays expensive.

“The problem is structural. Distribution requires massive pipeline networks and liquefaction plants that need billions in capital investment. Safety regulations and permitting processes are complex, so progress is slow.

“Most distribution infrastructure sits with a handful of major companies. They tend to share less knowledge than innovators in other hydrogen fields. In capital-intensive sectors where competitive advantage matters, companies are far less likely to publish innovations openly. This slows progress across the entire sector.”

Professor Dimitris Christopoulos who co-authored the findings is director of research for the Edinburgh Business School and Heriot-Watt University’s School of Social Science. He said: "We cannot have a hydrogen economy without the infrastructure to move it around. Right now, that is the fundamental missing piece.

“The 2015 Paris Agreement requires rapid scaling of clean energy technologies, but infrastructure bottlenecks could undermine major investment programmes. The question now is whether policymakers and industry will act before distribution costs make hydrogen uncompetitive.”

The findings reveal where the hydrogen system is most vulnerable showcasing that pipes, terminals and liquefaction plants needed to move hydrogen safely and affordably are lagging behind. This matters because distribution is what links the entire hydrogen system together. Without it, production stays concentrated near manufacturing sites, meaning the wider economy cannot make use of it and the climate benefits never materialise.

Professor Mercedes Maroto-Valer who leads the UK Industrial Decarbonisation Research and Innovation Centre (IDRIC), said: “As the BBC recently reported on Germany’s green hydrogen industry, hydrogen faces a classic chicken-and-egg problem: industry won’t commit at scale without pipelines, terminals and reliable delivery, but those networks won’t be built at scale without firm industrial demand. What this new Heriot-Watt research adds is hard evidence that distribution innovation moves much more slowly than the rest of the hydrogen system, so without targeted action to de-risk infrastructure, the distribution costs and uncertainty will keep holding the market back.”

Targeted policies, incentives for greater knowledge sharing, creation of open technical standards and publicly backed demonstration projects would all reduce risk for industry and speed up the development of viable distribution solutions.

The paper "Dynamics of knowledge production: A relational-event analysis of patent citation hazards in hydrogen technologies" was published in Sustainable Futures.

ENDS

Notes to editors

This work was supported by UKRI ISCF Industrial Challenge through the UK Industrial Decarbonisation Research and Innovation Centre (IDRIC), award number EP/V027050/1.

name: Congress
title: Swift, Allan “Al” Byron (1935-2018) - HistoryLink.org
description:
Perhaps signaling his later turn to politics, Swift noted that he "particularly enjoys interviewing political candidates" and that talking with "Governor [Dan] Evans made for enlightening conversation" ("Soroptimists Hear KVOS Broadcaster").
Entering Politics Swift first worked for Meeds as an administrative assistant, gaining experience before his own attempt at election.
Meeds represented a turn in state politics, particularly after his comments about the 1974 Boldt decision, which affirmed Native American fishing rights.
Lobbying and Retirement Having regularly moved between Washington state and Washington, D.C., Swift settled in Virginia following his retirement from Congress.
By 2018, Swift had retreated from public service entirely following a diagnosis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.
text:
Allan "Al" Swift represented Washington’s Second Congressional District as a Democrat for eight terms between 1979 and 1995, giving shape and form to the state’s reputation for forward thinking. His political career was marked by moments of environmental foresight, voter mobilization, and infrastructure support. Born in Tacoma, Swift attended Central Washington College before undertaking a career in broadcasting, where he mastered the art of communication and was awarded a regional Emmy for his work. Later, Swift moved into politics and was elected to represent five Washington counties at the congressional level in Washington, D.C.. Swift transitioned into increasingly influential positions, including the Energy and Commerce Committee and the House Administration Committee. Key bills guided by Swift included the Elwha River Restoration Act, National Voter Registration Act, and Amtrak Authorization Act. By 1994, he had helped oversee 177 bills progress into law, and worked across the aisle to achieve results for the state. Leaving Congress, Swift held a series of lobbying positions in Virginia before his death in 2018 at the age of 82.

Media Man

Allan Byron Swift was born in Tacoma on September 12, 1935. One of two sons of a Coca-Cola truck driver, Swift lived on McKinley Hill in the center of town. His mother served as a superintendent of a Sunday school, and it was in Tacoma where Swift met his future wife, Paula Jackson, at the age of 12. He attended Lincoln High School and served as the editor of the student newspaper. His brother, Larry Swift, remarked to The Seattle Times that Al "became very interested in radio as a young boy" to the extent that he set up a mock station room at home ("8-Term Washington Congressman ..."). Following high school, Swift attended Whitman College in Walla Walla from 1953 to 1955 and then worked for KUJ, a radio station a short distance east of Tacoma – his first employed position in broadcasting proper. (KUJ continues to operate as of January 2026.) In 1957 he moved to Ellensburg, where he was employed by KXLE and graduated from Central Washington College.

Swift then moved to Bellingham and began a long tenure with KVOS-TV. Employed as director of news and public affairs, he covered a local events for an increasingly wide audience. The Anacortes American reported in 1972, for example, on Swift’s meeting with a local chapter of Soroptimists. Perhaps signaling his later turn to politics, Swift noted that he "particularly enjoys interviewing political candidates" and that talking with "Governor [Dan] Evans made for enlightening conversation" ("Soroptimists Hear KVOS Broadcaster"). By 1976 Swift had been awarded a regional Emmy for his programming on tide pools, and by 1977 he had joined the office of U.S. Congressman Lloyd Meeds (1927-2005), a Democrat from Washington’s Second Congressional District – a vast area including all of Whatcom, San Juan, Island, and Skagit counties, along with the most populous parts of Snohomish County. Thus began Swift's transformation into one of the state's longest-serving public officials.

Entering Politics

Swift first worked for Meeds as an administrative assistant, gaining experience before his own attempt at election. He was tasked with handling minor party operations and the general public. He was noted for having presented regional energy plans at the Skagit County Courthouse on behalf of the congressman in 1977. Meeds had become the representative for the district following a comfortable election victory in 1964, when he defeated incumbent Republican Alfred Westland (1904-1982). Meeds represented a turn in state politics, particularly after his comments about the 1974 Boldt decision, which affirmed Native American fishing rights. Meeds was derided for asking his constituents to move on from the issue. Following a narrow win in 1976, Meeds made plans to leave politics, opening a path for Swift to fill his seat.

On the campaign trail, Swift moved quickly to secure critical voting bases and appeared in the media with commentary designed to support small businesses, voter representation, and transportation. Speaking to the Anacortes American in June 1978, Swift declared his intent to oppose large oil tankers and a new terminal at Cherry Creek near Blaine, an issue that has been debated as recently as 2023. In September 1978, Swift held a campaign dinner in Mount Vernon, inviting members of the public to join him for an 'authentic Mexican' meal prepared by Greg and Mary Espinoza. Swift used events such as these to solidify his base, meet people, and capitalize on his communication skills. By late September, Swift had secured the Democratic nomination. His opponent was Republican John Nance Garner III. David Horsey (b. 1951), a reporter for The Eatonville Dispatch, covered part of the race, noting Swift’s "smooth style" and "aggressive, effective campaign" ("Campaign ’78: A Battle of Images"). Newspaper advertisements touted Swift’s record, including statements about the 1974 Boldt decision and his desire to 'restore equity' to fishing as well as financial policy.

Swift’s campaign was buoyed by Democrat support in November when Senator Henry Jackson (1912-1983) visited Anacortes and endorsed him. Primarily, Jackson spoke to the city’s concern for its industries, which faced increasingly tight restrictions on the disposal of contaminants and air quality. Swift won the election comfortably against Garner with a platform based on moderate, reasonable politics. By January 1979 he was in Washington, D.C., to begin the first of his eight terms of service to the district.

Busy in Both Washingtons

In the nation's capital, Swift took a no-nonsense approach to the environment. He introduced his first bill to the House of Representatives in 1979: House Bill 2821, which called on the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to construct further flood control along the Skagit River. While the bill didn’t pass, it coincided with Swift doubling down on construction concerns and other infrastructure related to water, power, and transportation. He is noted for having publicly supported the Northwest Power Act, which provided a regional model for collaborative management of hydroelectric infrastructure. Also in 1979, Swift went toe to toe with representatives from Texaco and the Shell Oil Company over a potential project in the Cherry Point area. Swift insisted that a pipeline be built to replace regular tanker trips, citing the reduction of potential harm to the environment, and greater efficiency with the ultimate goal of saving taxpayer funds. Ultimately, environmentalist resistance killed the Cherry Point project entirely, but Swift continued to explore energy issues, charged by the economic 'stagflation' of the 1970s.

Before the end of 1980, Swift had introduced three bills regarding power and infrastructure in the state, and spoken publicly about increasing demands for future development. His first successful bill, however, didn't come until 1983 with the passing of HR 3376, which explicitly recognized land held in trust for the Makah Tribe. It followed a series of remediation efforts over the status of fishing in the state, and crucially preserved the rights gained in the Boldt case almost a decade before. Swift would provide emergency consultations for other fishermen as the industry continued to suffer economic hardships across the decade.

By 1985, Swift had won re-election comfortably three times and continued to meet community members as issues changed in the state. Healthcare became an increasingly important topic, and Swift spent much of 1985 discussing elder care, Medicare, and hospital management. In March 1985, he returned to Bellingham to host a forum on the issue and address the concerns of senior citizens. Now established with the day-to-day operations of a sitting congressman, Swift navigated Ronald Reagan's presidency and a changing world. He started that year on his second bill, which would be passed and signed into law. HR 4393, known as the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, repealed two previous acts regarding voting rights and set the precedent for a later piece of legislation. In essence, the act further developed the rights of U.S. citizens to participate in elections from outside the country. Post offices were instructed to provide materials for this purpose free of charge, including write-in ballots, campaign materials, and absentee-ballot applications. This less-than-controversial bill passed both the House and Senate without amendment and was signed into law in August 1986, before the campaign cycle began again.

Main Bills

Once again winning re-election, Swift looked to increasingly complex issues for legislative challenges. He had by 1986 secured positions on several committees, including the Energy and Commerce Committee and the House Administration Committee. Both gave Swift a broad understanding of D.C. politics and how to leverage bipartisan support for infrastructure. These experiences would allow Swift to become a "workhorse" congressman, sponsoring and cosponsoring a series of important bills ("Former U.S. Rep. Al Swift ...").

The Rail Safety Enforcement and Review Act demonstrated some of Swift’s political tact. Passed by the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and then the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, the bill included a series of stipulations relating to rail regulations. Specifically, the bill required the Secretary of Transportation to further tighten safety protocols for maintenance workers and issue equipment for working on bridges. Power brakes on locomotives, radios, hazardous materials, and penalties had all been attended to in the wording of the bill. A pilot program was established to assign litigators to regional offices, with several previous laws being revised in the process.

There were ample reasons to improve rail safety. A 1989 incident in San Bernardino, California, in which a Southern Pacific Railroad freighter demolished several houses and killed four people, had heightened concern just a few years before. In 1987, an Amtrak passenger train accident in Maryland resulted in 16 deaths. The Rail Safety bill passed into law by the end of 1992, without much opposition. Simultaneously, Swift helped pass the Amtrak Authorization and Development Act, which focused much less on safety regulations and more on the ability of the company to finance expanding operations. Also in 1992, Swift helped restore Amtrak service between Seattle and Vancouver, B.C. This service is still in use as of 2026, having been halted for the duration of the COVID-19 pandemic, and returning as travel restrictions were lifted.

Dam Buster

Swift’s experience with environmental and power-related issues would come to bear on HR 4844, the Elwha River Ecosystem and Fisheries Restoration Act. Designed to end the legal debate over the Elwha and Glines Canyon dams on the Olympic Peninsula, it provided a framework for dam removal and established a precedent for tribes, fishing interests, and states working around endangered species and aging hydropower. Specifically, after consultation with the city of Port Angeles, the Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe, Bonneville Power Administration, and other stakeholders, the bill instructed the Secretary of the Interior to acquire both dams. Further, it provided replacement power from the BPA grid and money for a tribal cultural facility.

Debates over the structures had started as early as 1937, following their construction by Canadian entrepreneur Thomas Aldwell (1868-1954) from 1910 to 1927. The wide variety of opinions and stakeholders, however, had halted a majority of removal attempts until the dams came up for relicensing in 1973. The Lower Jamestown S’Klallam, the National Park Service, and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration intervened in the application process and began a formal legal process to initiate removal. Swift worked with these groups, the town of Port Angeles, the dam owners, and the public to secure an agreement and pass it into law in October 1992. Successive congressional sessions would deliberate over where the funding to acquire the dams would come from, resulting in a delay of two decades between the act and final removal. The project continues to mark a significant moment in the management of large-scale infrastructure not only in Washington but also in the wider Pacific Northwest. The act, little appreciated before the final removal of the dams in 2010 and 2014, has since been the blueprint for removals such as the Klamath River project in Oregon and Northern California.

Upon passage of the bill, Swift wrote a private letter to President George H. W. Bush (1924-2018) requesting "the pen you use to sign HR 4844, the Elwha River Ecosystem and Fisheries Restoration Act" ("Letter to President ..."). Internal documents from Swift’s office, now housed at the Center for Pacific Northwest Studies in Bellingham, detail Swift's deep sense of satisfaction following the vote.

More Victories

Swift also helped pass the 'Motor Voter' bill during this period, which became effective in May 1993. Building on his previous bill regarding overseas voting, HR 2 streamlined the methods by which U.S. citizens could be registered to vote. At a federal level, this meant that anyone who submitted an application for a driver's license was automatically registered to vote unless they decided to opt out. Furthermore, the act protected voters from being removed from the registry for changes of address, unless there was no change notice provided. Again, Swift had demonstrated his ability to work within the fine grain of regulation for the benefit of all, and not simply those who shared his party affiliation. It is unsurprising then that the bill was cosponsored by more than 73 members of Congress. It would mark the last piece of major legislation authored by Swift, although he continued to support other efforts.

Later in 1993, he cosponsored legislation introduced by Republican congresswoman Nancy Johnson (b. 1935) to extend Medicare policies, and another bill introduced by Republican Elton Gallegly (b. 1944) to permit penalty-free withdrawals on retirement funds for emergency expenses. But the eight terms of service that Swift had conducted for Washington and the nation were coming to an end. In 1992, Swift had announced that he wanted just one more term before retiring from his post. He had led a successful office for over a decade, passing major bills and working closely with allies such as Democrat Norm Dicks (b. 1940), who represented Washington's Sixth District for 36 years.

Republicans Jack Metcalf (1927-2007) and Tim Erwin, and Democrat Harriet Spanel (1939-2016) competed for the soon-to-be vacant seat. Metcalf prevailed easily, ending the longstanding Democratic representation in the Second District.

Lobbying and Retirement

Having regularly moved between Washington state and Washington, D.C., Swift settled in Virginia following his retirement from Congress. He continued to apply his knowledge of railroad legislation and management, serving as vice president of government affairs for Burlington Northern Railroad. Serving only a year before the company merged with Atchison, Topeka, and Santa Fe, Swift briefly started his own consultancy before joining as a partner at Colling, Swift & Hynes. The Virginia-based lobbying group employed several public figures, including Robert Hynes (1936-2023), a former legislative vice president at NBC, and lobbyist Pablo Colling.

Swift worked with companies such as Eastman Kodak to advance interests in the halls of power and continued to engage with national politics in a variety of capacities. In 2006, he appeared before a Senate committee to provide testimony on lobbying regulations alongside Senator Barack Obama (b. 1961) and Senator John McCain (1936-2018), among other notable figures. The debate over lobbying featured a variety of opinions and discussed alternative regulations, notably whether or not meals should be regulated. By 2007, the firm's client list had grown to include the government of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Media General Inc., the Newark Group, and Quest Diagnostics.

The remainder of Swift’s working career was spent in this way. He continued to review regulations, government materials, and other legislative documents. In one of his final visits to Washington state, and last public comments, Swift toured the site of the removed Elwha and Glines Canyon dams on the Olympic Peninsula. Overlooking the watershed by air and on foot, he told Cascadia Weekly that he was "very impressed with the work and that salmon have already returned to their former habitat above the dams" ("The Week That Was").

By 2018, Swift had retreated from public service entirely following a diagnosis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. He died on April 20, 2018. The Seattle Times published an obituary and editorial, noting Swift’s fondness for jazz and cigars, and his dedication to public service.

name: Texas American Energy
title: Wisconsin utilities expand clean energy as U.S. prepares to exit Paris Climate Agreement
description:
GREEN BAY (WLUK) -- As the United States prepares to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement, utilities in Wisconsin are ramping up their clean energy initiatives.
The Environmental Protection Agency reports that the electric power sector contributes about 25% of all U.S. greenhouse gas emissions.
Wisconsin Public Service is actively working to reduce this impact by expanding its renewable energy facilities, including solar, hydroelectric and wind energy.
"We provide reliable clean energy to our customers every day using our renewable energy facilities," WPS spokesperson Matt Cullen said.
Despite the end of federal tax credits for solar panel installations, WPS customers can still benefit from clean energy projects, which have provided tens of millions of dollars in savings.
text:
GREEN BAY (WLUK) -- As the United States prepares to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement, utilities in Wisconsin are ramping up their clean energy initiatives.

The Environmental Protection Agency reports that the electric power sector contributes about 25% of all U.S. greenhouse gas emissions.

Wisconsin Public Service is actively working to reduce this impact by expanding its renewable energy facilities, including solar, hydroelectric and wind energy.

"We provide reliable clean energy to our customers every day using our renewable energy facilities," WPS spokesperson Matt Cullen said.

WPS recently launched Wisconsin's first large-scale battery storage facility, which stores energy for later use when demand is high. Additionally, WPS offers programs like NatureWise and the renewable pathway program, allowing customers and businesses to choose how their electricity is generated.

Despite the end of federal tax credits for solar panel installations, WPS customers can still benefit from clean energy projects, which have provided tens of millions of dollars in savings. WPS aims to be net carbon neutral by 2050 and has already reduced emissions by 56% since 2005.

title: MOORE: Why hasn't Trump repealed Biden's $50B backdoor business tax increase?
description:
The Trump administration took a well-deserved victory lap last week for repealing more than 100 Biden-era rules for every new regulation.
Business partnerships are a common legal form of American business arrangements.
Back in September, The Wall Street Journal pummeled the Biden rules as an “extralegal” plot to go around Congress and squeeze higher business taxes out of employers.
The Trump administration has supercharged the U.S. economy for 2026 in no small part by repealing these kinds of Biden-era antibusiness taxing and regulating policies.
Stephen Moore is a former Trump senior economic adviser and the cofounder of Unleash Prosperity.
text:
The Trump administration took a well-deserved victory lap last week for repealing more than 100 Biden-era rules for every new regulation. This will save U.S. businesses potentially hundreds of billions of dollars of unnecessary costs. Gone are discriminatory racial preferences, Green New Deal mandates and electric vehicle mandates — to name a few.

President Donald Trump has solidly established himself as the “deregulation president.”

That’s why it’s an ongoing mystery why the Trump Treasury Department and IRS have refused to repeal one of former President Joe Biden’s most onerous rules of all: targeting business partnerships for $50 billion of new tax liabilities. Business partnerships are a common legal form of American business arrangements.

This giant stealth tax increase was never voted on or approved by Congress. It appears to be a blatant violation of the constitutional requirement that all tax bills start in the House of Representatives. The House never even saw this tax hike coming. Talk about a “danger to democracy.”

The U.S. has more than 4 million partnerships — employing more than 10 million people — that could be affected.

Many small family businesses use partnership arrangements routinely.

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the Heritage Foundation, Americans for Tax Reform, the National Taxpayers Union and the Job Creators Network have all urged the GOP to rescind the Biden backdoor tax increase.

Back in September, The Wall Street Journal pummeled the Biden rules as an “extralegal” plot to go around Congress and squeeze higher business taxes out of employers. The WSJ noted that the tax hike was finalized just days before Trump took office as part of the quest for more revenue to pay for trillions of dollars of budget-busting programs.

These partnership rules are “functioning like the administrative state’s own version of a deep state rebellion,” writes my friend and Unleash Prosperity colleague Steve Forbes. They are nothing more than a tool for “punishing Main Street.”

He’s right. The regulations created a new IRS auditing SWAT team with agents whose sole purpose is to harass partnerships in a guilty-until-proven-innocent “compliance” process. Several companies are facing multibillion-dollar retroactive tax assessments that go back four to five years. These are deductions on activities that were previously untaxed under the IRS code. So much for the rule of law.

The Trump administration has supercharged the U.S. economy for 2026 in no small part by repealing these kinds of Biden-era antibusiness taxing and regulating policies.

Former Trump chief economist Larry Kudlow is predicting 4% to 5% growth for the year ahead. Reaching that ambitious target would be an amazing feat made all the easier to achieve if the Trump IRS would repeal the most conspicuous remaining antibusiness Biden policy: the $50 billion sucker-punch assault on legal business partnerships.

Stephen Moore is a former Trump senior economic adviser and the cofounder of Unleash Prosperity.

title: Tesla Fires Up America's First Major Lithium Refinery | OilPrice.com
description:
This week, Tesla North America and Elon Musk announced that the largest and most advanced lithium refinery in the United States is now operational.
The Tesla Lithium Refinery just outside of Corpus Christi, Texas, is another step toward the U.S. goal of having domestic refined lithium resources to counter China’s market dominance.
“Our Lithium Refinery ushers in energy independence for North America,” Tesla North America said in the caption of a video announcing that the plant is operational, just two years after breaking ground.
The company’s new domestic lithium refinery is one of the first concrete steps for America to reduce dependence on refined lithium supply on China.
That’s to ensure access to a domestic supply of key minerals and create jobs in the minerals supply chain.
text:
This week, Tesla North America and Elon Musk announced that the largest and most advanced lithium refinery in the United States is now operational.

The Tesla Lithium Refinery just outside of Corpus Christi, Texas, is another step toward the U.S. goal of having domestic refined lithium resources to counter China’s market dominance.

“Our Lithium Refinery ushers in energy independence for North America,” Tesla North America said in the caption of a video announcing that the plant is operational, just two years after breaking ground.

The refinery converts spodumene ore directly into battery-grade lithium hydroxide, in a first-of-its-kind process in North America.

Tesla uses a new technology platform that allows a cleaner, simpler, and cheaper process to obtain battery-grade lithium from the raw material, spodumene ore, says Jason Bevan, Site Manager for Tesla’s Gulf Coast Lithium Refinery.

Tesla says it sustainably sources spodumene and brings it to site where it runs it through a series of conveyance systems, takes it through a kiln and a cooler. From there, the material is taken through an alkaline leech and additional purification steps, and then into crystallization to produce battery-grade lithium hydroxide.

“Our process is more sustainable than traditional methods and eliminates hazardous byproducts and instead produces a co-product named anhydrite used in concrete mixes,” a refinery employee says in the Tesla video.

Tesla notes that this refinery enables it to have access to the critical minerals for energy storage, for battery manufacturing, and ultimately for EV growth.

The first-of-its-kind lithium refinery in North America also enables Tesla to accelerate its mission by “regionalizing supply chains for battery minerals and materials, by providing jobs, by cutting emissions from transportation that's required for those supply chains.

“It really allows us to usher in energy independence for North America,” Tesla says.

The company’s new domestic lithium refinery is one of the first concrete steps for America to reduce dependence on refined lithium supply on China.

The U.S. has been trying for years to break that industrial and national security dependence on critical minerals used in battery technology and defense, military, and automotive technologies.

The Trump Administration took this fight a notch up by directly investing, through the Departments of Defense and Energy, in minority stakes in North American lithium producers and refiners. That’s to ensure access to a domestic supply of key minerals and create jobs in the minerals supply chain.

The U.S. Administration is increasingly looking to have a direct equity involvement in America’s critical minerals supply chain, in the race to close the gap with China.

Direct Administration bets on lithium mining projects were a key theme in the sector last year.

For example, the Department of Energy (DOE) has agreed to provide a $2.26 billion loan to Vancouver-based Lithium Americas Corp. to help it complete a major lithium project in Humboldt County in northern Nevada.

For the first draw on the DOE loan, the Department received a 5% equity stake in Lithium Americas through warrants to purchase common shares, as well as a 5% economic stake in Lithium Americas’ joint venture with GM for the Thacker Pass lithium project in Nevada.

Lithium Americas targets late 2027 for the mechanical completion of the Thacker Pass project, in which GM last year bought a 38% interest for $625 million in total cash and letters of credit.

Thacker Pass is expected to be the biggest lithium supply project in the Western hemisphere. Thacker Pass alone is expected to raise nearly ten times the current U.S.-sourced lithium volumes.

In addition, in July 2025, U.S. rare earths miner and magnet producer MP Materials Corp announced it had entered into a public-private partnership with the Department of Defense (DoD) to accelerate the build-out of an end-to-end U.S. rare earth magnet supply chain and reduce foreign dependency.

The direct involvement of the U.S. federal government highlights the importance the Administration places on securing domestically-sourced critical minerals and reducing dependence on foreign suppliers, most notably China.

By Charles Kennedy for Oilprice.com
